articles.title: About the INSPIRE-STROKE
articles.contents:
What is INSPIRE-STROKE?

Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability globally. With recent advancements in the availability of electronic health data, new opportunities exist to leverage Big Data (e.g. population-level administrative or registry data) being collected around the world to gain deeper insights on the health impacts of stroke globally.


INSPIRE-STROKE was established in 2023 to address current gaps in the surveillance of stroke globally, across important treatment outcomes such as:

Readmissions
Medication utilisation
Mortality
Health economics
Patient-reported outcomes

This network of international researchers collaborate and apply standardised methods to assess and report health outcomes following stroke to inform policy and practice.

Our Vision

The vision of INSPIRE-STROKE is to create an enduring system for routine international pooling of Big Data on important stroke outcomes that are not covered in current systems.

INSPIRE-STROKE will monitor outcomes following stroke by:
Comparing country-level observational data
Fostering a scientific community to facilitate international benchmarking
Using advanced methods and best-practice standards to ensure findings are reliable and robust.
How INSPIRE-STROKE Works?


The INSPIRE-STROKE Coordinating Centre has been approved by Monash University Human Research Ethics Committee (Approval no. 41990) to conduct this project.

Funding

The initial establishment of INSPIRE-STROKE is being funded by a pilot project grant awarded from the STOPstroke NHMRC Synergy Grant (1182071). Research fellowship support has also been obtained from the National Heart Foundation of Australia for investigators A/Prof Kilkenny (105737) and Dr Dalli (107125).

articles.title: INSPIRE-STROKE
articles.description:
International Network for Standardised Population Insights
and Real-world Evidence for STROKE
articles.contents:
Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability globally
Tackling the burden of stroke will require international collaboration and data-driven solutions to advance health policy and practice

articles.title: To Get Involved
articles.contents:
Potential Benefits

Learn and apply new analysis techniques
Generate novel evidence for policy and practice
Opportunity to co-author publications (where authorship criteria are fulfilled)
Collaborate with international leaders in stroke researchers
Enhance your research profile

What is involved?

Collaborators will be invited to contribute to working groups and publications focused on addressing important research questions aligned with the INSPIRE-STROKE themes.
Collaborators will perform analyses on their local data and share aggregated summary outputs for data pooling. Collaborators will need access to person-level stroke data that is representative of a geographic region.
Working groups will meet regularly via teleconference to progress projects, at times convenient for most collaborators.
Additional input and comment will be sought occasionally by email.
There will be opportunities to join the INSPIRE-STROKE steering committee and lead future research studies.
While overarching ethics has been obtained, each collaborator is responsible for seeking appropriate approvals specific to their dataset.

Please email us if you’d like to join
